summary_variants.short_answer: A circular economy is an industrial system designed to minimize waste and keep materials in use through reuse, repair, remanufacture, and recycling.
summary_variants.kid_friendly: In a circular economy, people try to make things last longer by fixing, sharing, and recycling instead of throwing them away.
summary_variants.standard: The circular economy framework seeks to decouple growth from resource use by designing products for durability, maximizing reuse loops, and recovering nutrients and materials at end-of-life. It blends industrial ecology principles with policy tools such as extended producer responsibility.
summary_variants.expert_notes: Include Ellen MacArthur Foundation's butterfly diagram, EU Circular Economy Action Plan, metrics (material circularity indicator), and critiques about rebound effects.

slots.definition: An economic model focused on regenerative design that keeps products, components, and materials at their highest utility for as long as possible.
key_characteristics: Keep products and materials in circulation
applications: Organic waste composting and nutrient recovery
limitations: Potential rebound effects if total consumption rises
history: Popularized by the Ellen MacArthur Foundation (2010s)
